verses.text: But now, Job, listen to my words; pay attention to all I say.
verses.comment: Elihu appeals to Job personally, inviting him to listen. This signals a transition to a new speaker who claims special insight.

verses.text: See now, I open my mouth; my tongue in my mouth speaks.
verses.comment: Elihu asserts his intention to speak clearly and truthfully, showing confidence in his role as mediator.

verses.text: My words come from an upright heart; my lips sincerely speak what I know.
verses.comment: The theme of sincerity and integrity echoes the biblical virtue of speaking truth from the heart (cf. Psalm 15:2).

verses.text: The Spirit of God has made me, and the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
verses.comment: Elihu credits his existence and insight to the Spirit of God—the reference to the 'breath' connects to creation, highlighting dependence on God’s inspiration.

verses.text: If you can, answer me; set your words in order before me; stand up.
verses.comment: A courtroom motif: Elihu invites Job to defend himself like one presenting a case before a judge, evocative of approaching God with respect.

verses.text: Look, I am like you before God; I too was formed from clay.
verses.comment: Elihu reminds Job of their shared humanity, both having a common Creator—hinting at the theme of solidarity among believers.

verses.text: No fear of me should terrify you, nor should my hand be heavy on you.
verses.comment: Elihu offers reassurance, contrasting human counsel with the awe-inspiring presence of God.

verses.text: Surely you have spoken in my hearing, and I have heard the sound of your words:
verses.comment: He quotes Job, preparing to respond directly. Faithful listening is a prerequisite for true counsel (cf. James 1:19).

verses.text: "I am pure, without guilt; I am clean, and there is no wrongdoing in me.
verses.comment: Elihu paraphrases Job’s claims, demonstrating that self-righteousness is under scrutiny.

verses.text: Yet God finds reasons against me and counts me as his enemy;
verses.comment: Job’s perceived alienation from God echoes the human sense of separation due to suffering, pointing toward the need for reconciliation.

verses.text: He puts my feet in the stocks and watches all my paths."
verses.comment: Imagery of bondage and watchful surveillance—Job feels imprisoned by God’s scrutiny.

verses.text: "But I tell you, in this you are not right, for God is greater than a human being.
verses.comment: Elihu challenges Job’s presumption, emphasizing God's transcendent ways—this anticipates Romans 9:20, where Paul asks, 'Who are you, O man, to answer back to God?'

verses.text: Why do you complain against him that he does not give an account of all his doings?
verses.comment: Elihu rebukes Job for demanding justification from God, which subtly reflects the call to humility before divine mystery.

verses.text: For God speaks in one way, and in another, though people do not perceive it.
verses.comment: This reveals the idea of God's multi-faceted revelation (cf. Hebrews 1:1)—God reaches us in various ways, often unrecognized.

verses.text: In a dream, in a vision of the night, when deep sleep falls on people, as they slumber on their beds,
verses.comment: Dreams and visions are recognized as legitimate means of divine communication (see Joel 2:28; Acts 2:17).

verses.text: then he opens their ears and terrifies them with warnings,
verses.comment: God’s revelation often comes to awaken or warn—this prepares the heart for repentance (see Jonah 3:5-10).

verses.text: to turn a man from wrongdoing and keep him from pride,
verses.comment: Divine correction is meant for salvation, not condemnation. This foreshadows God's discipline of those He loves (see Hebrews 12:6).

verses.text: to preserve his soul from the pit, his life from perishing by the sword.
verses.comment: The 'pit' is often an image of Sheol, the abode of the dead. God’s correction is life-saving.

verses.text: Man is also disciplined with pain on his bed, with constant distress in his bones,
verses.comment: Physical suffering as divine discipline anticipates the redemptive value of suffering seen in the cross (cf. 2 Cor 4:17).

verses.text: so that his life loathes bread, and his soul despises the choicest food.
verses.comment: Suffering can cause detachment from earthly pleasures, which spiritually prepares the soul for deeper conversion.

verses.text: His flesh wastes away, so it cannot be seen, and his bones, once hidden, now stick out.
verses.comment: A vivid description of severe illness—alluding to the frailty and mortality of man.

verses.text: His soul draws near the pit, and his life to those who bring death.
verses.comment: Approaching death is seen as nearing Sheol. The need for redemption becomes clear here.

verses.text: If there is a messenger for him, a mediator, one among a thousand, to show a man what is right for him,
verses.comment: The concept of a 'mediator' points ahead to the New Testament’s high priestly ministry of Christ, the one true Mediator between God and man (1 Tim 2:5).

verses.text: and he is gracious to him and says, 'Deliver him from going down to the pit; I have found a ransom,'
verses.comment: The term 'ransom' (Hebrew 'kofer') evokes sacrificial language, prefiguring the redemptive work fulfilled in Christ’s sacrifice (Mark 10:45).

verses.text: then his flesh shall become fresher than in youth; he shall return to the days of his youthful strength.
verses.comment: Restoration follows redemption—this has spiritual parallels in the life of grace and ultimate resurrection.

verses.text: He prays to God, and He accepts him; he sees His face with a shout of joy, and God restores his righteousness to him.
verses.comment: God’s acceptance is seen through prayer and restoration—anticipating New Testament reconciliation through repentance and faith (James 5:16; Luke 15:21-24).

verses.text: He sings before men and says, 'I have sinned and perverted what was right, and it was not repaid to me.'
verses.comment: Open confession leads to forgiveness; this is at the heart of true repentance (cf. Psalm 32:5; 1 John 1:9).

verses.text: He has redeemed my soul from going down to the pit, and my life shall see the light.
verses.comment: A clear anticipation of the hope of resurrection—seeing the light (cf. John 8:12), a biblical image of salvation.

verses.text: Behold, God does all these things, twice, three times, with a man,
verses.comment: God’s persistent mercy is highlighted, emphasizing repeated opportunities for conversion.

verses.text: to bring back his soul from the pit, that he may be enlightened with the light of life.
verses.comment: A strong expression of God’s desire to save, foreshadowing the Christian understanding of salvation and new life in Christ (cf. John 1:4, John 8:12).

verses.text: Pay attention, Job, listen to me; be silent, and I will speak.
verses.comment: Elihu urges Job to listen—reception and obedience to wisdom are recurring biblical themes (cf. Proverbs 2:2).

verses.text: If you have anything to say, answer me; speak, for I desire to justify you.
verses.comment: The desire for justification foreshadows the New Testament emphasis on justification before God. There is an implicit invitation to reconciliation.

verses.text: If not, listen to me; be silent, and I will teach you wisdom.
verses.comment: The closing call to learn wisdom echoes biblical tradition, in which true wisdom is ultimately found in God’s self-revelation and instruction.
